questions.text: The diagram given below depicts a mechanism of separation of the placenta. What is this mechanism called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Schultz

Explanation:

 

 

                                                                                    

Feature

Central Separation (Schultze)

Marginal Separation (Mathews-Duncan)

Initiation

Starts at the center of the placenta

It starts at the margin of the placenta

Relation with uterine contractions

Detachment occurs as uterine contractions increase

Detachment occurs as uterine contractions increase

Blood Accumulation

Leads to retroplacental hematoma

-

Mechanism

Weight of the placenta and blood facilitate detachment

Marginal areas are unsupported, leading to separation

Frequency

Less common

More common

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, pregnant with her second child at 38 weeks, is admitted to the labor and delivery unit due to decreased fetal movements. A cardiotocography (CTG) is performed, revealing a baseline fetal heart rate of 130 beats per minute with decelerations. These decelerations vary in shape, timing, and duration, often occurring independently of contractions and sometimes appearing as "V" or "W" shapes. Based on the CTG findings described, what is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Umbilical cord compression 

Explanation:

  • Umbilical cord compression leads to variable decelerations, which are abrupt, irregular, and not tied to contraction peaks, sometimes appearing as "V" or "W" shapes.
  • When variable decelerations are associated with uterine contraction, their onset, depth, and duration commonly vary with successive uterine contractions

questions.text: During routine monitoring at 36 weeks gestation, a pregnant woman shows a non-reassuring fetal heart rate pattern on CTG. The observed waveform is smooth and undulating, with a fixed frequency (3-5 cycles/min) and amplitude (5-15 bpm). The fetal heart rate ranges 120-160 bpm. Which CTG pattern is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Sinusoidal pattern

Explanation:

The sinusoidal pattern, describing a smooth, regular fetal heart rate oscillation is associated with severe fetal anaemia or maternal opioid use

A sinusoidal pattern in a cardiotocography (CTG) trace resembles a sine wave, with a stable fetal heart rate (FHR) and fixed or absent baseline variability lasting more than 30 minutes. Accelerations are absent in a true sinusoidal pattern. This pattern is often associated with:

  • Fetal anaemia
  • Fetomaternal haemorrhage
  • Vasa Previa
  • Fetal hypoxia (acidosis)

A sinusoidal pattern can also occur when the mother has been given narcotics.

The pseudo sinusoidal pattern shows a 'saw-toothed' pattern. It differs from the true sinusoidal pattern because it indicates a well-oxygenated fetus.

Acceleration pattern (Option A): Reassuring fetal status
Saltatory pattern (Option B): Sign of fetal distress
Variable deceleration pattern (Option D): Linked to umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A 30-year-old first-time mother at 39 weeks gestation arrives at the labor and delivery unit with regular contractions. A cardiotocography (CTG) is performed, which reveals a baseline fetal heart rate of 140 beats per minute with periodic decelerations. These decelerations begin early in the contraction phase, reach their lowest point at the peak of the contraction, and return to baseline by the end of the contraction. Based on the CTG findings described, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Fetal head compression

Explanation:

Early decelerations, characterised by a gradual decrease in fetal heart rate that mirrors contractions, are primarily linked to fetal head compression. This is usually benign and occurs during active labour as the fetal head descends into the pelvis.

Interpretation of CTG :

  • Baseline FHR: Average FHR between contractions (110-160 bpm). Abnormal ranges indicate fetal distress.
  • Baseline Variability: Fluctuations in baseline FHR reflect nervous system balance. Reduced variability may indicate hypoxia, acidosis, or other factors.
  • Accelerations: Transient FHR increases with fetal movement, indicating a healthy fetus with intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular function.
  • Decelerations: Transient FHR decreases below baseline.

Types of Decelerations:

Type

Characteristics

Cause

Early Decelerations

Gradual decrease mirroring contractions.

Fetal head compression (Option C)

Late Decelerations

Begin after contraction peak, uniform U-shaped.

Fetal hypoxia, uteroplacental insufficiency (Option A, D)

Variable Decelerations

Abrupt, irregular, "V" or "W" shapes.

Umbilical cord compression (Option B)

questions.text: A 32-week pregnant woman with gestational hypertension presents during a routine prenatal visit with elevated blood pressure. Ultrasound shows normal fetal growth, but there is concern about fetal well-being due to maternal hypertension. What is the most appropriate next step to monitor fetal status?

choices.text: Doppler ultrasound of the middle cerebral artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Non-stress test (NST)

Explanation:

  • Gestational hypertension qualifies as a high-risk pregnancy, even if fetal growth is currently normal.
  • The NST is a first-line, non-invasive tool to assess fetal oxygenation and autonomic integrity by evaluating fetal heart rate accelerations in response to movement.
  • It provides real-time information about fetal well-being, especially in hypertensive disorders.
  • If NST is nonreactive or equivocal, it may be followed by BPP or Doppler studies as needed.

High-Risk Pregnancy Fetal Surveillance Modalities

Modality

Description

Use in High-Risk Pregnancy

Maternal Perception of Movement

Self-reported decrease in fetal kicks

Basic screening, not sufficient alone in hypertensive cases

Non-stress Test (NST)

Heart rate monitoring with fetal movement

First-line in hypertension, IUGR, and other high-risk cases

Contraction Stress Test (CST)

Heart rate response to contractions

Rarely used today; backup when NST is equivocal

Biophysical Profile (BPP)

Combines NST + ultrasound for movement, tone, breathing, AFI

Follow-up after abnormal NST or in chronic conditions

Modified BPP

NST + Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI)

Quick screening method in high-risk pregnancy

Doppler Velocimetry

Blood flow in umbilical or MCA vessels

Used in IUGR, anemia, or advanced hypertensive disease

Cardiotocography (CTG)

Continuous electronic fetal monitoring

In labor or inpatient high-risk settings

Real-Time Ultrasound

Assess growth, fluid, and fetal anatomy

Adjunct to other methods
  • NST is recommended as the first-line surveillance tool in high-risk pregnancies like hypertension.
  • MCA Doppler is more useful when there's evidence of fetal anemia or IUGR, not when growth is normal. (Option C)
  • Fetal echocardiogram is used when congenital cardiac defects are suspected, not for routine hypertension. (Option A)
  • Maternal movement monitoring is helpful but subjective, and not adequate for high-risk conditions alone. (Option B)

questions.text:
A 28-year-old primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She reports no concerns and states that she feels the baby moving regularly. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated thus far. Her obstetrician decides to perform a biophysical profile (BPP) due to a recent history of decreased fetal movements. The BPP results are as follows:


	Fetal breathing movements: 1 episode of 30 seconds within 30 minutes
	Gross body movements: 3 discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes
	Fetal tone: no movement
	Amniotic fluid volume: Single vertical pocket measuring 2 cm
	Non-stress test (NST): Reactive


What is the recommended management for this patient?

choices.text: Continue routine prenatal care and follow-up as scheduled

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Continue routine prenatal care and follow up as scheduled 

Explanation:

The biophysical profile score:

2 (breathing) + 2 (movements) + o (tone) + 2 (amniotic fluid) + 2 (NST) = 8 points indicates that the fetus is not in distress and is well-oxygenated. Routine prenatal care is appropriate, and the patient should continue with her scheduled follow-up appointments.

 

Biophysical Profile (BPP) is a prenatal test used to assess fetal well-being, particularly in high-risk pregnancies. It combines ultrasound imaging with the Non-Stress Test (NST) to evaluate five biophysical parameters

Biophysical Profile:

 

Component

Normal Criteria

Abnormal Criteria

Points

Fetal Breathing Movements

At least 1 episode of ≥30 seconds in 30 minutes

Absent or no episode of ≥30 seconds in 30 minutes

2 (normal)

0 (abnormal)

Gross Body Movements

At least 3 discrete body/limb movements in 30 minutes

Less than 3 discrete body/limb movements in 30 minutes

2 (normal)

0 (abnormal)

Fetal Tone

At least 1 episode of active extension with a return to flexion

Slow extension with partial return or no movement

2 (normal)

0 (abnormal)

Amniotic Fluid Volume

At least 1 pocket of amniotic fluid measuring ≥2 cm in vertical depth

Largest vertical pocket <2 cm

2 (normal)

0 (abnormal)

Non-Stress Test (NST)

Reactive (2 or more FHR accelerations of ≥15 bpm for ≥15 seconds within 20 minutes)

Non-reactive (less than 2 accelerations within 20 minutes)

2 (normal)

0 (abnormal)

 

Interpretation of Biophysical Profile Score:

 

  • 8-10: Normal, reassuring; suggests a healthy, well-oxygenated fetus.
  • 6: Equivocal; may need to repeat testing or further evaluation.
  • 4 or less: Abnormal; indicates possible fetal compromise and often warrants immediate intervention.

 

Modified Biophysical profile: AFI and NST are the parameters used. It takes only 10 min to perform.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1 woman at 28 weeks gestation presents to the clinic with complaints of increased abdominal size and shortness of breath. On physical examination, her abdomen appears larger than expected for gestational age. An ultrasound reveals an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 30 cm. What is the incorrect statement regarding this condition?

choices.text: Anencephaly is a possible cause for this condition.
It can cause premature rupture of membranes.
Indomethacin cannot be used to treat this condition.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D)Indomethacin cannot be used to treat this condition

Explanation:

 The clinical vignette suggests polyhydramnios, but the incorrect statement regarding this condition is that indomethacin cannot be used to treat it.

Polyhydramnios is an excessive amount of amniotic fluid, often diagnosed when the AFI is >= 25 cm or the SDP is >= 8 cm.

 

CAUSES OF POLYHYDRAMNIOS

Increased fetal urine production

Impaired fetal swallowing
  • Twin/multifetal pregnancy
  • Maternal hyperglycemia/diabetes
  • Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome
  • Cleft lip and cleft palate.
  • Esophageal atresia or stenosis.
  • Duodenal atresia or stenosis.
  • Bowel obstruction.
  • Anencephaly.

Placental causes

Fetal causes
  • Chorangioma of placenta.
  • Circumvallate placenta.
  • Hydrops fetalis.
  • Rubella, syphilis, and toxoplasmosis.
  • Trisomy.
  • Sacrococcygeal teratoma.
  • Thalassemia of the fetus.

 

Management of polyhydramnios:

  • Serial amniocentesis (treatment of choice): Fluid is removed at a rate of 500 mL/hr, maximum up to 1500-2000 mL).
  • Indomethacin 1.5-3 mg/kg/day:
    • Reduced fetal urinary output and increased fluid reabsorption via lungs.
    • It can cause premature closure of patent ductus arteriosus; hence therapy should be stopped at 32 weeks.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P1, at 36 weeks of gestation, presents for a routine prenatal visit. She reports decreased fetal movements over the past two days. On examination, her uterus measures smaller than expected for gestational age. A non-stress test is non-reactive, and an ultrasound is performed, which reveals a single deepest vertical pocket of 1.5 cm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Oligohydramnios 

Explanation:

Oligohydramnios is defined as a decreased amount of amniotic fluid. It is diagnosed when the AFI is less than 5 cm or the SDVP is less than 2 cm. In this scenario, the SDVP of 1.5 cm confirms the diagnosis of oligohydramnios.

Oligohydramnios:

Criteria
  • Amniotic fluid index <5 cm.
  • Single deepest vertical pocket <2 cm.
  • Amniotic Fluid Volume less than 500 mL.

Causes
  • Uteroplacental insufficiency
  • Premature rupture of membranes (PROM)
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Fetal renal anomalies
  • Maternal dehydration
  • Medications (e.g., ACE inhibitors).

Complications
  • Umbilical cord compression
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Preterm birth
  • Stillbirth
  • Labour complications (e.g., meconium aspiration, cesarean delivery)

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasound to measure AFI and SDVP.
  • Non-stress test (NST) and biophysical profile (BPP) for fetal assessment.

Treatment
  • Amnioinfusion during labour for severe cases.
  • Maternal rehydration.
  • Delivery planning is based on gestational age and fetal status.
  • Normal amniotic fluid volume is indicated by an AFI between 5-24 cm or a single deepest vertical pocket between 2-8 cm. The findings in this scenario fall below these ranges.
  • Preterm labour refers to labour that occurs before 37 weeks of gestation. While the patient is at 36 weeks, there is no mention of contractions or cervical changes that would indicate preterm labour. The primary concern in this scenario is the decreased amniotic fluid volume, not labour.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation comes to the antenatal clinic for her routine check-up. The obstetrician decides to perform a non-stress test (NST) to assess fetal well-being. Which of the following is not a parameter evaluated during a non-stress test (NST)?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Contraction frequency

Explanation:

Contraction frequency is not a parameter evaluated during an NST. It is more relevant in a contraction stress test (CST) or during labor monitoring.

NST specifically assesses fetal heart rate patterns without considering uterine contractions.

Non-Stress Test (NST):

  • It is a non-invasive test used to assess fetal well-being by monitoring the fetal heart rate and its response to fetal movements.
  • It is typically performed in the third trimester of pregnancy.
  • The mother is placed in a semi-reclining position, and two belts are placed around her abdomen to measure the fetal heart rate and detect fetal movements.

Primary parameters evaluated during an NST:

1. Baseline Fetal Heart Rate (FHR)

2. Beat-to-beat Variability

3. Accelerations

4. Decelerations

5. Fetal movements

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman from a remote area visits your clinic for her first prenatal checkup. She is in her first trimester and has had no prior antenatal visits. Considering the challenges of her location, you discuss the importance of antenatal care. What is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended by the WHO for a pregnant woman to ensure a healthy pregnancy and childbirth?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B)8

Explanation:

The current WHO recommendation is for a minimum of eight antenatal visits during pregnancy. This change was made to provide more opportunities for monitoring, timely detection of potential complications, and appropriate interventions.

In India, the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare recommends a minimum of four antenatal visits for pregnancy. The ideal number of recommended visits is 12-15.

  • 0-28 weeks: 1 visit/4 weeks
  • 28-36 weeks: 1 visit/2 weeks
  • 36 weeks to childbirth: 1 visit/week.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the 4th stage of labour is false?

choices.text: Period to ensure the health of mother and baby
Mother can be sent to the ward if she is vitally stable, her uterus is well retracted, and there is no abnormal vaginal bleeding.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) None of the above

Explanation:

  • 4th stage of labour is one hour of observation after the delivery of the fetus, placenta, and membranes.
  • It is done to ensure the well-being of the mother and baby.
  • Pulse, BP, tone of the uterus, and vaginal bleeding are watched for at least an hour.
  • The mother can be sent to the ward if she is vitally stable, her uterus is well retracted, and there is no abnormal vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: Which among the following statements on the first stage of labour is false?

choices.text: The upper uterine segment contracts and the lower uterine segment dilates.
During contraction, maternal heart rate and systolic blood pressure increase.

questions.solution:
Correct answer : A)Dilation precedes effacement

Explanation:

In the first stage of labour, effacement happens first, then dilatation.

 

Aspect of First Stage of Labour

Description

Onset
  • Intermittent painful uterine contractions followed by the expulsion of blood-stained mucous(show) from the vagina.

Uterine Contractions
  • Painful, involuntary, and gradual increase in frequency and intensity.
  • Intervals between contractions shorten from approximately 10 minutes to as little as 1 minute or less.

Cervical Changes
  • Effacement (shortening and thinning of the cervix) and dilation (opening of the cervix up to 10 cm) occur progressively during labour.Effacement precedes dilation.

Distinct Uterine Segments
  • The upper segment contracts firmly.
  • The lower segment remains softer and passive to facilitate fetal descent.

Maternal Physiological Changes
  • Increased heart rate and systolic blood pressure during contractions; relaxation between contractions essential for uteroplacental blood flow.

questions.text: ‘The palmar surface of the fingers of the left hand is placed above the symphysis pubis and the body of the uterus is pushed upward and backward. By the right hand, a steady tension is given in a downward and backward direction holding the clamp.’ What is this method of placenta expression called?
questions.solution:
Correct answer : B) Modified Brandt-Andrews method

Explanation :

Synonyms

Controlled cord traction

Method

  • The palmar surface of the left hand is positioned above the symphysis pubis at the junction of the upper and lower uterine segments.
  • The uterus is gently pushed upward and backwards toward the umbilicus while the right hand exerts steady, gentle traction downward and backwards on the clamp until the placenta is expelled.

Prerequisite

The uterus is hard and contracted.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of early cord clamping?
questions.solution:
Correct answer : D) Hypertensive mother

Explanation:

Delayed cord clamping means clamping the umbilical cord ≥ 1-3 minutes of birth. The advantage of this is that 80 ml of blood (approximately 50 mg of elemental iron) in the cord goes to the newborn, preventing neonatal anaemia.

It is done for all deliveries with some exceptions, where early cord clamping is recommended.

  • Situations where early cord clamping is considered :
    • The baby is hypoxic and needs resuscitation.
    • Maternal hemorrhage &/or hemodynamic instability.
    • Placental circulation not intact - cord avulsion.
    • Known hear disease in newborn (relative indication).
    • Rh incompatibility (relative indication).

questions.text: Which among the following is the first-line uterotonic agent during labour?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Oxytocin 

Explanation :

Oxytocin is preferred as the first-line uterotonic agent.

Oxytocin:

  • It is the recommended drug by WHO for preventing post-partum haemorrhage.
  • Dose: 10 units i.m or i.v infusion.
  • It is an octapeptide synthesised in the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus, transported to the posterior pituitary, stored there, and released into the bloodstream if needed.
  • It has a half-life of 3-5 minutes and is stored at 2-8℃.
  • Uses:
    • First-line uterotonic agent.
    • Induction and augmentation of labour.
    • It is responsible for milk ejection.
  • Oxytocin should not be given as an IV bolus due to the risk of marked transient fall in BP, an abrupt increase in cardiac output, and cardiovascular collapse.
  • Due to its ADH-like action, it can cause water intoxication, leading to hyponatremia, seizures, and coma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Active Management of the third Stage of Labor-AMTSL?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : C) Uterine massage 

Explanation:

Uterine massage is no longer a part of active management of third stage of labour as per latest WHO guidelines.

Steps of AMTSL:

  • Use of uterotonic (oxytocin) after the birth of the baby (5-10 IU IM at delivery of the anterior shoulder).
  • Delayed cord clamping (≥ 1-3 minutes).
    • Wait for 60 seconds.
    • Increases the Hb of the baby by 1g% (preventing neonatal anemia).
    • Contraindicated in:
      • Fetal distress
      • HIV/HbsAg positive mother
      • Rh-negative mother
  • Delivery of the placenta by controlled cord traction (Modified Brandt Andrews method).
  • Intermittent assessment of uterine tone.

 

 

Advantages of AMTSL
  • Minimised Blood Loss
  • Shortened Duration

Disadvantages
  • Slightly increased incidence of retained placenta
  • Risk of asphyxia in the second twin if administered prematurely.

Indications

High-risk factors include anaemia, hydroamnios, twins, grand multiparae, and a previous history of postpartum haemorrhage (PPH).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 24 hours after a vaginal delivery with complaints of severe perineal pain and difficulty with bowel movements. Upon examination, a third-degree perineal tear is diagnosed. What is not done as the next step in management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) immediate repair of the tear

Explanation:

For third-degree perineal tears presenting more than 24 hours after delivery, immediate repair is typically not recommended due to the increased risk of infection.

The appropriate management involves starting broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent infection and planning for surgical repair after a three-month period.

Management:

  • Immediate Repair: After placenta delivery to reduce infection risk and blood loss.
  • Delayed Repair: If >24 hours, start antibiotics and wound care & plan for delayed repair (secondary repair) once the wound if free of exudate and infection.

Initiate broad-spectrum antibiotics (Option B): It is done in delayed presentation of third-degree tears to prevent or manage infection. Antibiotics cover common perineal flora and help reduce the risk of wound sepsis. 

Provide pain management & wound care (Option C): It is essential and appropriate in both immediate and delayed presentations. Wound care, sitz baths, analgesics, and stool softeners are standard supportive measures.

Plan for delayed repair (Option D): It is the appropriate course of action for tears diagnosed >24 hours after delivery. It allows inflammation to subside and ensures better healing conditions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida gave birth to a healthy baby boy of 4 kg. She sustained an injury to the perineum involving internal and external anal sphincters. Which degree of perineal tear is this?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Third Degree

Explanation:

Degrees of perineal tear

Description

First Degree (Option A)

Injury to perineal skin only.

Second Degree (Option B)

Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter.

Third Degree (Option C)

Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both external and internal):

  • 3a: <50% of EAS thickness torn
  • 3b: >50% of EAS thickness torn
  • 3c: Both EAS and IAS torn

Fourth degree (Option D)

Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS) and anal epithelium.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about episiotomy repair is true?

choices.text: Absorbable sutures are used in the perineal muscle layer
The perineal muscle layer should be sutured with tension
Vaginal mucosa should be sutured starting from the base
Hemostasis can be achieved after sutures are placed

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Absorbable sutures are used in the perineal muscle layer

Explanation: 

Absorbable sutures like polyglycolic acid (dexon) or chromic catgut suture the perineal muscle layer during episiotomy repair.

Episiotomy repair:

  • Timing:
    • Done soon after the expulsion of the placenta to prevent wound disruption and reduce the risk of infection (sepsis).
    • Early repair also helps alleviate patient discomfort and anxiety about sutures.
  • Principles to be Followed:
    • Perfect Hemostasis: Ensure bleeding is controlled completely before proceeding with each layer of suturing.
    • Obliterate Dead Space: Close the wound layers tightly to prevent the formation of pockets where fluid can accumulate.
    • Suture Without Tension: Avoid pulling the tissues too tightly together, as this can lead to poor wound healing and cosmetic outcomes.
  • Order of repair:
  1. Vaginal mucosa and submucosa
  2. Perineal muscles
  3. Skin and subcutaneous tissue

 

Layer

Description

Vaginal Mucosa and Submucosal Tissues
  • Sutured starting at or above the apex of the tear.
  • Interrupted sutures with Polyglycolic acid (Dexon) or No. '0' Chromic Catgut.

Perineal Muscles
  • Absorbable sutures like Polyglycolic acid (Dexon) or Chromic Catgut.

Skin and Subcutaneous Tissues
  • Absorbable or non-absorbable sutures depending on preference and wound characteristics.

questions.text: Given below is the instrument used in a procedure done in the second stage of labor. What is the most commonly performed type of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Mediolateral

Explanation:

Given is an image of episiotomy scissors. The most prevalent type of episiotomy is mediolateral episiotomy.

we give epsiotomy at the ti me of crowning at 60 degree angle from the midline  

Types of episiotomy:

 

Type

Advantages

Disadvantages

Mediolateral
  • Reduced risk of severe perineal tears.
  • May facilitate easier delivery.
  • Less risk of injury to the anal sphincter compared to the midline.
  • Higher risk of postpartum pain and discomfort.
  • Potential for increased blood loss compared to other types.
  • It may not be suitable for all cases, depending on perineal anatomy.

Median
  • Simplicity in execution.
  • Reduced risk of injury to the anal sphincter.
  • Less postoperative pain compared to mediolateral.
  • Higher risk of severe perineal tears, including anal sphincter injury.
  • Potential for increased healing time and complications due to midline orientation.

Lateral/
Transverse
  • Potential for reducing the risk of severe perineal tears compared to midline.
  • Less disruption to perineal body alignment.
  • May be quicker to perform in some cases.
  • Higher risk of complications such as Bartholin's duct injury.
  • Increased likelihood of uneven wound healing.
  • Not preferred due to the potential for structural damage and poor cosmetic outcomes.

T-shaped
  • Potential for minimising anal sphincter injury.
  • May provide better vaginal opening in complex deliveries.
  • Less risk of perineal tear extension.
  • Complex to perform.
  • Likely to cause puckering and imperfect wound closure.
  • Not widely recommended due to the potential for postoperative complications and difficult repair.

 

Steps of mediolateral episiotomy:

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is in labour. Delivery is getting delayed due to shoulder dystocia, and episiotomy is indicated. Which structures were not cut during this process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : D) Ischiocavernosus 

Explanation:

Muscles cut in episiotomy are levator ani, superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, and bulbospongiosus.

 

Aspect

Description

Definition
  • Surgically planned incision on the perineum and posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor
  • Considered a second-degree perineal injury.

Objective
  1. Enlarge the vaginal introitus for easier and safer delivery.
  2. Prevent overstretching and rupture of perineal muscles and reduce stress on the fetal head.

Indications
  • Rigid perineum
  • Anticipating perineal tear (big baby, face-to-pubis delivery, breech, shoulder dystocia)
  • Operative delivery
  • Previous perineal surgery

Timing
  • Ideally performed just before crowning (when 3-4 cm of the fetal head is visible) to minimise bleeding and maximize the protective effect.

Advantages
  • Maternal: Controlled incision heals better, potentially shortens the second stage, and reduces pelvic floor trauma.
  • Fetal: Minimizes intracranial injuries.

Structures cut

From outer to inner:

  • Skin and subcutaneous tissue.
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves.
  • Facia covering the muscles that are cut.
  • Muscles
    • Levator ani.
    • Superficial and deep transverse perinei.
    • Bulbospongiosus
  • Posterior vaginal wall

questions.text: Which of the following is an event in the second stage of labor?

choices.text: Expulsion of blood-stained mucous per vagina(show)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bearing down efforts 

Explanation:

Bearing down efforts are seen in the second stage of labour.

 

Aspect of Second Stage of Labour

Description

Definition

  • Full dilatation of the cervix to expulsion of the fetus.

Pain and Intensity
  • Pain intensifies with contractions

Bearing Down Efforts
  • Voluntary expulsive efforts due to vaginal stretching by the presenting part (head).
  • Efforts should coincide with uterine contractions.
  • Sustained pushing beyond contractions is discouraged.

Membrane Status
  • Membranes may rupture with a gush of amniotic fluid either before or during the descent of the fetus.
  • Rarely, the baby may be born in the caul (intact membranes).

Descent of the Fetus
  • Head rotation also occurs.

Vulva

  • 'Crowning' of the head occurs when the widest part of the head stretches the vulval outlet.
